title: 108_s501
content: The "Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003" establishes a grant program for gifted and talented students under Chapter B. This program includes authorized activities for supporting these students. The "Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003" recognizes that gifted and talented students require specialized services to fully develop their capabilities, regardless of cultural, racial, or socioeconomic background. Some of these students may have disabilities or English as a second language, and many come from historically underrepresented groups. Elementary school students who are gifted and talented have already mastered a significant portion of the material covered in a school year before it begins. Teachers receive training to meet the diverse needs of students in their classrooms. Most teachers receive training to meet the needs of diverse students, including those with limited English proficiency, disabilities, and from various cultural backgrounds. However, they often lack training to support gifted and talented students, who may not have access to private programs like some of their peers. Gifted education programs in public schools are crucial for high-ability students, especially those from disadvantaged backgrounds. Parents and families play a vital role in supporting the educational and emotional needs of gifted children. The curr_chunk discusses the lack of federal requirements to identify and serve gifted students, with varying resources and support at the state and local levels. The lack of federal requirements to identify and serve gifted students leads to varying resources and support at the state and local levels, resulting in disparities in services for this special-needs population. It is crucial for more students to achieve higher levels of education to meet future economic and national security needs, especially for highly capable students who need education that prepares them for innovative and creative work. The performance of twelfth-grade advanced students in the United States on international assessments was among the lowest in the world in physics and mathematics. In 1990, only a small fraction of education spending in the US went towards elementary and secondary education. In 1990, a minimal amount of funding was allocated for challenging programs for gifted students in the US. The Secretary may award competitive grants to State educational agencies for grants to local educational agencies if the appropriated amount is between $7,500,000 and $57,500,000. State educational agencies can receive grants to develop or expand gifted and talented education programs and provide direct educational services and materials. If the appropriated amount exceeds $57,500,000, the Secretary may award grants to State educational agencies for this purpose. State educational agencies can receive grants to develop or expand gifted and talented education programs and provide direct educational services and materials to gifted and talented students. Grant funds can be used for various activities outlined in the legislation. Grant funds provided under this chapter for gifted and talented students may include curriculum compacting, modified curriculum, acceleration, independent study, and dual enrollment. However, funds cannot be used for purchasing or upgrading technological hardware. State educational agencies receiving grants under this chapter are limited to using no more than 10 percent of the funds for dissemination of program information, technical assistance, and monitoring and evaluation of programs. State educational agencies can use funds for monitoring, evaluation, parental education support, and creating a State gifted education advisory board. Up to 50% of the funds can be used for administrative costs. "State educational agencies can use funds for monitoring, evaluation, parental education support, and creating a State gifted education advisory board. Up to 50% of the funds can be used for administrative costs. SEC. 5467A. ALLOTMENTS TO STATES." The Secretary reserves 1/2 of 1 percent of funds for programs in schools operated or funded by the Bureau of Indian Affairs. The remaining funds are allotted to states based on their populations of individuals aged 5 through 17. The Secretary allocates funds to states based on their populations of individuals aged 5 through 17. States receiving an allotment must not get less than \1/2\ of 1 percent of the total amount. If a state does not apply for funds, the Secretary will redistribute the amount to other states. "SEC. 5467B. State application for funds based on population of individuals aged 5 through 17. States must receive at least \1/2\ of 1 percent of total amount. Unapplied funds will be redistributed to other states." To be eligible for a grant under this chapter, a State educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary with assurances that funds will be used to support gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, including those with limited English proficiency and disabilities. The State educational agency must use funds to support gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, including those with limited English proficiency and disabilities, and ensure that the funds supplement, not supplant, state and local funds for education. The State educational agency must provide matching funds for gifted and talented student programs, develop assessment models for program accountability, and evaluate educational effectiveness. The State must implement program assessment models for accountability and educational effectiveness. The Secretary will approve State applications that meet the requirements of this section. "SEC. 5467C. DISTRIBUTION TO LOCAL EDUCATIONAL AGENCIES." A State educational agency must allocate at least 90% of the funds to local educational agencies through a competitive process for carrying out authorized activities. Grants are distributed equitably by geographic area within the State. The State educational agency allocates funds to local educational agencies through a competitive process for equitable distribution by geographic area within the State. Grants are awarded based on the needs of the students to be served. "Local applications for grants are allocated by the State educational agency based on student needs." To be eligible for a grant under this chapter, a local educational agency must submit an application to the State educational agency. The application must include an assurance that funds will be used to support gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, including those with limited English proficiency and disabilities. The local educational agency must ensure that funds received will supplement, not supplant, the amount expended for the education of gifted and talented students, including training personnel in this area. The State educational agency must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing the number of students served and activities supported with funds under the Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003. The report should also include measures taken to comply with specific sections. The Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003 allows recipients of funds to serve gifted students alongside those with similar needs. Private school children and teachers should have equitable participation in grants and professional development programs. Definitions are provided in the act. The Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003 defines 'gifted and talented' individuals based on applicable State law or definitions by educational agencies. The term 'State' in the Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003 refers to each of the 50 States, the District of Columbia, and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. If a State does not have a law defining a term, it is interpreted based on section 9101. Authorization of Appropriations for fiscal years 2004 through 2010 is set at $170,000,000, with $7,500,000 allocated for chapter A and the remainder for chapter 2. Technical and conforming amendments are made to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. In the context of authorizing appropriations for fiscal years 2004 through 2010, amendments are made to the Jacob K. Javits Gifted and Talented Students Education Program. This includes changing references from "this part" to "this chapter" and redesignating subsections within section 5464.
